awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Robust Modeling and Predictions of Stream Water Quality and Ecosystem Health
awd_abstract_narration:
1454435 (Abdul-Aziz). The goal of this research is to investigate and robustly predict the dynamics of stream water quality and ecosystem health in complex urban-natural basins (e.g., coastal urban centers).  The central research hypothesis is that urban stream biogeochemical and ecological processes follow emergent similitude, scale-invariant patterns and organizing principles, which will lead to spatiotemporally robust predictions of water quality and ecosystem health.  Specific research objectives are to (1) identify the dominant controls and quantify relative linkages of stream water quality and ecosystem health variables in relation to the hydro-climatic, watershed and land use, in-stream, and coastal drivers/stressors; (2) investigate the similitude (parametric reductions), scaling laws (emergent patterns), and organizing principles for stream water quality and health variables; and (3) formulate informatics based empirical (i.e., data-driven) and mechanistically based behavioral models as ecological engineering tools to obtain spatiotemporally robust predictions of urban stream water quality and ecosystem health.  The integrated educational objective is to develop an inductive-learning based interdisciplinary Ecological Engineering Pedagogy (EEP); in order to (1) increase retention of undergraduates and graduation of minority students in relevant STEM majors, (2) increase graduate students specializing in the emerging paradigm of ecological engineering, and (3) increase the number of K-12 students actively pursuing STEM educations/careers. The research will be primarily conducted in South Florida, a living laboratory and hot-spot for climate change and sea level rise; considering the region a prototype, case study of complex urban-natural environments around the world.  The research will also utilize nationally available data for other coastal urban centers (e.g., New York, Los Angeles, Houston), incorporating hydro-climatic, biogeochemical and ecological gradients across the U.S. coasts.

The research will employ a data-analytics and informatics framework to achieve mechanistic understanding on the dominant controls of urban stream water quality and ecosystem health processes.  It seeks to unravel the biogeochemical-ecological similitude and scaling laws for urban streams by deriving and utilizing appropriate dimensionless functional groups, which will identify the different environmental regimes and organizing principles of water quality and ecosystem health.  The scale-invariant patterns and emerging organizing principles will help to formulate parsimonious empirical and mechanistic behavioral models that, with nominal calibrations, can provide spatiotemporally robust predictions of stream water quality and health indicators.  The effort will utilize inductive learning methods to develop EEP case studies, involve minority undergraduates in research, and formulate simple Excel tools for K-12 students.  It will utilize inductive learning methods to develop EEP case studies, involve minority undergraduates in research, and formulate simple Excel tools for K-12 students.  Research outcomes will be shared with relevant agencies (e.g., Cities, County, NGOs) to improve their stream water quality and health management strategies.  The EEP case studies will be utilized to teach two new interdisciplinary courses (developed by the PI): Ecohydrological Engineering (undergraduate) and Ecological Engineering (graduate).  Research and educational outcomes will be broadly disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, graduate theses/dissertation, reports, YouTube, and a project website.  Local and regional high school students and teachers will be involved with the research-education by leveraging current and developing new collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
The project successfully investigated the dominant controls of coastal and inland stream water quality and ecosystem health across the contiguous US. New mechanistic insights and knowledge were obtained on the stream water quality and ecosystem health processes. The research led to the discovery of scale-invariant patterns and emerging organizing principles, which helped develop generalized models to robustly predict various stream water quality indicators (e.g., Dissolved oxygen, temperature, and biomass) across USA. The models can be leveraged as useful tools to promote environmental sustainability. The models were further represented as Excel-based user-friendly software for lay users. The developed models would reduce the cost of stream water quality monitoring projects. The research outcomes are expected to guide planning, monitoring and adaptive management of urban-natural water resources under a changing climate and environment. Furthermore, the knowledge of environmental controls on stream water quality, as well as the underlying ecological similitude and scaling patterns, can lead to enhanced understanding and management activities in fisheries science, biology, and other environmental sciences.

The project had significant impact on the development of human resources through its education component; which provided high school and university students multiple opportunities to achieve the knowledge, skills, and attitude for promoting sustainable water resources under a changing climate and environment at two universities: West Virginia University (WVU), and Florida International University (FIU). Four Ph.D. and two M.S. (thesis) students worked for the project under the supervision of the Principal Investigator (Dr. Omar I. Abdul-Aziz). Among them, two Ph.D. and the two M.S. (thesis) students graduated from WVU during 2017-2020. One Ph.D. graduate, Dr. Shakil Ahmed found a faculty position in a reputed university of Bangladesh. Another Ph.D. graduate, Dr. Mohammad Siddik joined in the Sarasota County Government, Sarasota, Florida as an environmental engineer. One M.S. graduate, Mr. Filmon Araya pursed an engineering position with a consulting company in Seattle, WA. Another minority student completed his M.S. (thesis) working for this project and continued his Ph.D. under the supervision of Dr. Abdul-Aziz; this student is scheduled to graduate in spring 2022. The other (4th) doctoral student is continuing his degree with another faculty colleague in civil engineering at WVU. All students have been trained and professionally developed with ecological engineering expertise, specializing on stream water quality, data-driven and empirical modeling, multivariate statistical analysis, and similitude and scaling analysis. Further, 12 undergraduate students (8 from the minority) worked on the project under the supervision of Dr. Abdul-Aziz and graduated on time. They were trained in data preparation, data analysis, programming in commonly-used software (Excel and MATLAB), simulations and stream water quality processes.

The findings of the CAREER project were disseminated by utilizing various platforms. The research objectives, activities, and findings were shared during 2015 to 2021with a large group of undergraduate and graduate students through six junior/senior level undergraduate and graduate classes. New curriculum materials through inductive learning-based pedagogies (e.g., case studies) were developed for the courses. Hands-on training on developing simple, spreadsheet-based models to predict stream water quality was provided to the high school students and teachers of Miami, FL and Morgantown, WV. They were trained on data collection and preparation, data analysis, computer programming, model simulations and predictions, and water quality processes in watersheds. The project resulted in two doctoral dissertations and two master’s theses in Civil and Environmental Engineering at WVU. An additional doctoral dissertation will be completed at WVU in Spring 2022.

The findings were broadly disseminated through presentations (total 20) and abstracts (20) in respected international conferences. Two peer-reviewed articles were published, and 12 additional journal manuscripts have been prepared based on the results from this project. Further, based on the project activities and findings, Dr. Abdul-Aziz convened and chaired 14 well-attended sessions on aquatic metabolism and surface water quality in the 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2021 Fall Meetings of the American Geophysical Union.

Overall, the project generated new knowledge and insights into the dominant controls of stream ecohydrological and biogeochemical processes, and provided scale-independent engineering tools and parsimonious models to robustly predict stream water quality and ecosystem health across the contiguous U.S. Research and educational outcomes have been broadly disseminated to improve scientific and public knowledge for their effective participation in stream water quality and ecosystem health management programs. The scientific understanding and models/tools generated from this research can be leveraged to develop effective management criteria for achieving sustainable water resources under the U.S. Clean Water Act Section 303(d) Program. This would help water quality managers, engineers, and scientists achieve and maintain healthy stream water quality in the contiguous U.S. and beyond. Further, the project involved and trained many high school and university students—representing mostly the minority and disadvantaged communities in the U.S.—to meet the demand of critical expertise on sustainability under a changing climate and environment.
